from IPython.display import Image
import pandas as pd
pd.options.display.max_colwidth = 180
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.express as px
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import plotly.figure_factory as ff
from plotly.subplots import make_subplots
from statsmodels.graphics.mosaicplot import mosaic
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
from colorama import Fore
r = Fore.RED
g = Fore.GREEN
y = Fore.YELLOW
b = Fore.BLUE
m = Fore.MAGENTA
c = Fore.CYAN

meta.columns = ['Key Name', 'Description']
meta.index = [i for i in range (1, 20)]

source.4852a95b:

plt.figure(figsize = (8, 8))
fig = sns.heatmap(df_analyzed.corr().iloc[1 : , 1 : ], annot=True, mask=matrix, cmap = "cividis_r")
fig.set(title = 'Correlation between Numerical Features')
plt.show()

source.d129e1cb:
fig = make_subplots(rows = 3, cols = 2)
fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x = df_analyzed['Current Annual Change CI (%)'], name = 'Current Annual Change CI (%)', nbinsy = 10), 1, 1)
fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x = df_analyzed['Long-term Trend CI (%)'], name = 'Long-term Trend CI (%)', nbinsy = 10), 2, 1)
fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x = df_analyzed['Distribution Range Size CI (units of 10,000 sq. km.)'], name = 'Distribution Range Size CI (units of 10,000 sq. km.)', nbinsy = 10), 3, 1)
fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x = df_analyzed['Current Annual Change (%)'], name = 'Current Annual Change (%)', nbinsy = 10), 1, 2)
fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x = df_analyzed['Long-term Trend (%)'], name = 'Long-term Trend (%)', nbinsy = 10), 2, 2)
fig.add_trace(go.Histogram(x = df_analyzed['Distribution Range Size (units of 10,000 sq. km.)'], name = 'Distribution Range Size (units of 10,000 sq. km.)', nbinsy = 10), 3, 2)

fig.update_layout(barmode='overlay')
fig.update_traces(opacity=0.75)

fig.show()

source.f547d9cd:
fig = make_subplots(rows = 3, cols = 2, specs=[[{"type": "pie"}, {"type": "pie"}], [{"type": "pie"}, {"type": "pie"}], [{"type": "pie"}, {"type": "pie"}]])
fig.add_trace(go.Pie(labels = df[df['IUCN Status'] == 'Least Concern']['Current Status'].value_counts().index, values = df[df['IUCN Status'] == 'Least Concern']['Current Status'].value_counts().values, name = 'Least Concern'), 1, 1)
fig.add_trace(go.Pie(labels = df[df['IUCN Status'] == 'Vulnerable']['Current Status'].value_counts().index, values = df[df['IUCN Status'] == 'Vulnerable']['Current Status'].value_counts().values, name = 'Vulnerable'), 1, 2)
fig.add_trace(go.Pie(labels = df[df['IUCN Status'] == 'Near Threatened']['Current Status'].value_counts().index, values = df[df['IUCN Status'] == 'Near Threatened']['Current Status'].value_counts().values, name = 'Near Threatened'), 2, 1)
fig.add_trace(go.Pie(labels = df[df['IUCN Status'] == 'Endangered']['Current Status'].value_counts().index, values = df[df['IUCN Status'] == 'Endangered']['Current Status'].value_counts().values, name = 'Endangered'), 2, 2)
fig.add_trace(go.Pie(labels = df[df['IUCN Status'] == 'Critically Endangered']['Current Status'].value_counts().index, values = df[df['IUCN Status'] == 'Critically Endangered']['Current Status'].value_counts().values, name = 'Critically Endangered'), 3, 1)
fig.update_traces(hole=.4)
fig.update(layout_showlegend = True)
fig.update_layout(title_text = "Current Status for IUCN Status", annotations=[dict(text = 'Least Concern', x = 0.0, y = 1.1, font_size = 14, showarrow = False), dict(text = 'Vulnerable', x = 0.7, y = 1.1, font_size = 14, showarrow = False), dict(text = 'Near Threatened', x = -0.05, y = 0.7, font_size = 14, showarrow = False), dict(text = 'Endangered', x = 0.7, y = 0.7, font_size = 14, showarrow=False), dict(text = 'Critically Endangered', x = -0.095, y = 0.3, font_size = 14, showarrow = False)])

source.4bb9add5:
fig, axes = plt.subplots(3, 2, figsize=(15,12))

mosaic(df.loc[df['Long Term Status'] == 'Strong Increase'], ['Distribution Status'], title = 'Strong Increase', label_rotation = 0.0, labelizer = lambda k: df.loc[df['Long Term Status'] == 'Strong Increase']['Distribution Status'].str.count(k[0]).sum(), ax = axes[0][0])
mosaic(df.loc[df['Long Term Status'] == 'Moderate Increase'], ['Distribution Status'], title = 'Moderate Increase', label_rotation = 0.0, labelizer = lambda k: df.loc[df['Long Term Status'] == 'Moderate Increase']['Distribution Status'].str.count(k[0]).sum(), ax = axes[0][1])
mosaic(df.loc[df['Long Term Status'] == 'Stable'], ['Distribution Status'], title = 'Stable', label_rotation = 0.0, labelizer = lambda k: df.loc[df['Long Term Status'] == 'Stable']['Distribution Status'].str.count(k[0]).sum(), ax = axes[1][0])
mosaic(df.loc[df['Long Term Status'] == 'Moderate Decline'], ['Distribution Status'], title = 'Moderate Decline', label_rotation = 0.0, labelizer = lambda k: df.loc[df['Long Term Status'] == 'Moderate Decline']['Distribution Status'].str.count(k[0]).sum(), ax = axes[1][1])
mosaic(df.loc[df['Long Term Status'] == 'Strong Decline'], ['Distribution Status'], title = 'Strong Decline', label_rotation = 0.0, labelizer = lambda k: df.loc[df['Long Term Status'] == 'Strong Decline']['Distribution Status'].str.count(k[0]).sum(), ax = axes[2][0])

axes[2,1].set_axis_off()
fig.suptitle('Distribution Status for each Long Term Status')
fig.show()

source.f4bb7d9d: 🔔 Birds species that were thought to be stable and unceratin long term seem to be uncertain, stable, or declining currently for the most part. They are rarely increasing currently. As expected, the increasing and declining species long term follow the same trend currently as well. A few examples of the strongly declining species long term as well as currently are presented below.
source.27d9ebec: MISSING VALUES
source.4e94233b: DISTRIBUTION STATUS FOR EACH LONG TERM STATUS
source.8d4355b1: PRELIMINARY ANALYSIS
source.cf3043a8: 📌 The least concerning species are either only stable or increasing with mostly positive long term trends. The concerning species seem to be declining with negative long term trends. Though some species are currently uncertain, from the boxplot above, they have similar traits to that of declining species. The least concerning species which are strongly increasing have a high current annual change as high as 11%. The critically endangered species which are strongly declining have a low current annual change as low as -18%. Examples of these species are presented below.
source.cc13da90: 🎆 Though IUCN Status is Least Concern, it is suprising that 30% of those bird species are currently declining. On the other hand, endangered species are all strongly declining. Currently increasing species are only amongst least concerning species and none of the concerning species. A few examples from these observations are presented below.
source.3a3f5168: HOW DO ALL THE TRENDS RELATE TO THE DISTRIBUTION STATUS FOR CONCERNING SPECIES?

source.8f2c42cf: LONG TERM STATUS Vs CURRENT STATUS
source.aa02281d:
BIRDS

**Can you imagine life without birds?! They are not just creatures that beautify our planet but they also contribute to the balance and the operation of our ecosystem. As humans, we are responsible for their endangerment and preservation.** ***Birds are wherever we are. They are our companions. Birds are mediators between heaven and earth.
—Terry Tempest Williams*** ![34-min.jpg](attachment:a18640ab-d85a-4bc9-a24a-e8c404a6f7f9.jpg) **Few of the many benefits of birds are as follows.**
  1. Pest Control
    2.
  2. Pollination and Seed Dispersal
  3. Scavenging
  4. Nutrient Cyling
  5. Soil Reformation
  6. Nature's Clean-up Crew
  7. Transform Landspaces
  8. Keep Coral Reefs Alive

source.b2af11a0:
ABOUT THE DATASET

**The State of India’s Birds report is the first comprehensive assessment of the distribution range, trends in abundance, and conservation status for most of the bird species that regularly occur in India. With their ubiquity and ecological importance, birds are excellent indicators of the state of our natural world and are potent cultural symbols of nature. This national-level assessment of birds is a significant step forward in the monitoring and conservation of India’s rich and varied biodiversity.** ![35-min.jpg](attachment:ce5b1173-45fd-4faa-a60a-ad2592ec8c47.jpg) **The State of India’s Birds report was created to assess the conservation status of the majority of species that regularly occur in the country. Worldwide, common and widespread species are declining; but in India, lack of information has meant that conservation attention has been focussed on only a few species (usually large, charismatic and threatened).** **The report fills this gap by using over 10 million observations uploaded to the eBird platform by more than 15,500 birdwatchers to evaluate the distribution range size of 867 Indian birds, and their trends in abundance in both the long term (over 25+ years) and currently (past 5 years). Using these three measures, plus information from the IUCN Red List of global threat status, this report places Indian species into Low, Moderate and High categories of Conservation Concern for India. A large number of species that are thought to be common and widespread find themselves as of High Conservation Concern.** ![36-min.jpg](attachment:c1e306ba-ee14-4369-9c46-0f4eaf2a0e94.jpg)

#### **LINKS!** **DATASET: https://www.kaggle.com/usharengaraju/state-of-indias-birds-2020**
**SOURCE: https://www.stateofindiasbirds.in/#soib_report**
source.f91487c1: 🎉 Schedule-IV and V comprise mostly the least concerning bird species. Schedule-I appears to be more than Schedule-IV for critically endangered species. Examples for each WLPA schedule in endangered species are presented below.

source.342ed03c: ⚡ The long term declining species have low long term trends and distribution ranges while the long term increasing species have a high long term trends and distribution ranges. Therefore, yellow points are towards the bottom left corner. For high status of conservation concern, only declining long term species exist. While in the low status of conservation concern, only uncertain or stable long term species exist. In moderate status of conservation concern, mostly declining long term species exist. Since they are species of concern, there are more declining species. Also, note that even though some species have a low or moderate status of conservation concern, they do not have any long term increasing species. This explains why they are concerning species. A few examples from the graph above are presented below.
source.9ff2708b: 💡 All the missing values in the data imply to the bird species that were not assesed for long term trends or current trends or both (Checked in the code block above). As seen in the bar chart, the missing data accounts to 56%. It wouldn't make sense to impute all of these values. Also, cannot discard these attributes as they are very essential in understanding the underlying distribution and relationships between features in the data. Hence, EDA shall be performed on completely analyzed species of birds.
source.ece5d041: INSTALL PACKAGES
source.e5ff325f: 🌟 Confidence Interval in Statistics is a range of values where in there is a fair probability that the true value exists. A higher CI indicates that there is a high uncertainity in estimation. Therefore, the lower the CI, the better. By visualizing histograms for the parameters and their respective CIs, a good CI can be choosen. Since the range of values for current annual change and its CI are not that wide, a CI of 10.0 is selected. Long term trend and its CI having a wider range, a CI of 30.0 is choosen. This is done to eliminate instances that are too inaccurate.

source.5186f399: 🪔 The long term declining species have low long term trends and distribution ranges while the long term increasing species have a high long term trends and distribution ranges. Therefore, green points are towards the top right corner and the yellow points are towards the bottom left corner. For high status of conservation concern, only strongly declining long term species exist. While in the low status of conservation concern, mostly increasing, uncertain or stable long term species exist. In moderate status of conservation concern, no increasing long term species exist. Since they are species of least concern, there are more non declining species. A few examples from the graph above are presented below.
source.ae8db3e4: ❤ There is a pattern in the images of birds that appear throughout the notebook. A few conclusions can be made by just glancing at the notebook that Vultures (White-rumped Vulture, Indian Vulture, and Red-headed Vulture) are of high status of conservation concern. On the other end of the spectrum, species like Rock Pigeon and Asian Koel are of low status of conservation concern. All species that have IUCN status as low concern don't mean that they are not in danger. A good example is the Pacific Golden Plover. Its IUCN status is low concern but is of high status of conservation concern. Another example is the Woolly-necked Stork, its IUCN status is vulnerable and has a negative long term trend and current annual change. Nevertheless, it is of low status of conservation concern as it has a very large distribution status. Note that all these estimates are of high certainity.

source.0a81d62b: 📍 The species with high long term trends, current annual changes, and distribution ranges have a very large distribution status. The species with low trends have a moderate distribution status. As seen in the bubble chart above, the bubbles that are further to the left, low, and small are red whereas the ones that are further to the right, top, and big are green. Since they are species of least concern, the number of species that are not largely distributed are not as high. A few examples from the graph above are presented below.
